makers.displaydate: born 1968, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia; active Addis Ababa
makers.displaymaker: Elias Sime, born 1968, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia; active Addis Ababa

texts.textentryhtml: Sime collects the materials for his relief sculptures at the Merkato, the largest open-air market on the African continent; it covers several square miles in Addis Ababa. He focuses his efforts on a section of the market called Menalesh Terra—which translates as “what do you have?”—where discarded items are fashioned into new products or sold for scrap. “I prefer things that have touched or been in contact with people,” Sime explains. The artist buys parts of discarded computers and machines for their raw materials and uses them to construct monumental wall hangings. He created the swirling atmospheric pattern of this work by braiding plastic- coated copper wire, weaving it into interlocking biomorphic shapes, and tacking them into place with nails. The result suggests both a painterly abstraction and a vast topography: the long horizon of the ocean, a cloudscape, or the rolling hills of a desert landscape.
Elias Sime, the artist, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, consigned; to [James Cohan Gallery, New York, New York], sold; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2022.
